topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Kayvon Beykpour, his Periscope acquisition into Twitter, his role leading Twitter consumer product, and previews topics including Elon’s takeover, culture change, and product lessons.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Enterpret (customer feedback intelligence) and OneSchema (embeddable CSV importer).

topics.title: Meeting Elon and Walter Isaacson present
topics.summary: Kayvon recounts being contacted to help get Elon up to speed right after the acquisition, meeting via FaceTime then in-person at Twitter HQ, and realizing Walter Isaacson silently observed the conversation for his reporting/book.

topics.title: Did Kayvon influence Elon’s Twitter plans?
topics.summary: Kayvon explains he likely didn’t shape Elon’s management approach, but did recommend strong internal leaders and brainstorm product directions; he highlights continued investment in Community Notes, Spaces, Communities, and creator monetization.

topics.title: How Kayvon was fired during paternity leave
topics.summary: Kayvon details the leadership transition from Jack to Parag, the shift from functional org to GM structure, and being let go shortly after his daughter’s birth—right as Twitter signed the term sheet to sell to Elon.

topics.title: Elon’s ‘come hang out’ product invitation
topics.summary: Kayvon shares Elon’s informal offer to return and ‘swipe left/right’ on whether to stay, and why Kayvon chose to move on—recognizing the difficulty of being a product leader between a strong founder and the org.

topics.title: From stagnant Twitter to shipping constantly
topics.summary: They discuss Twitter’s burst of feature shipping under Kayvon’s tenure and what it takes to shift a risk-averse culture, including the political difficulty of change in a functional org and the need for top-level alignment.

topics.title: Refine the core vs bold new bets
topics.summary: Kayvon explains how ‘refine the core’ (ranked timeline, recommendations, notifications) reignited growth but also increased risk aversion; his mission became balancing core optimization with ambitious new capabilities.

topics.title: Sacred cows as a roadmap for innovation
topics.summary: Kayvon describes identifying Twitter’s ‘sacred cows’ (character limits, reply control, annotations, feed assumptions) and using them as a roadmap for experimentation; he shares the ‘hide replies’ story as a culture microcosm.

topics.title: Portfolio approach: reliability plus new capabilities
topics.summary: They dig into balancing proven growth levers with speculative bets, including examples like fixing onboarding/SMS verification issues and continuing ML-driven improvements while still investing in new product surfaces.

topics.title: Using acquihires to drive bold initiatives
topics.summary: Kayvon explains how Twitter used small acquisitions to bring in founder-operators to lead risky bets (Spaces, Communities, Birdwatch/Community Notes, Fleets, creator monetization), and why protecting these teams from org drag mattered.

topics.title: Staffing: belief and obsession over availability
topics.summary: Kayvon argues teams fail when staffed by availability rather than conviction; for speculative projects especially, you need people who believe in the idea to ‘will it into existence,’ otherwise execution becomes toxic and slow.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Heap (automatic product analytics capturing user behavior across platforms).

topics.title: Jobs-to-be-done backlash and framework fatigue
topics.summary: Lenny asks about Jobs-to-be-Done and other frameworks; Kayvon says he disliked how JTBD was rolled out at Twitter, found it exhausting and not helpful, and hints the issue may be more about implementation than the framework itself.
